questions.text: A 36-year-old male HIV patient presents to the ED with a cough with bloody sputum. He also has night sweats, chills, and difficulty in breathing. A chest X-ray and examination of the sputum show the following findings. Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray and gram-staining is suggestive of Nocardiosis. The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole.

Nocardia is a gram-positive and acid-fast bacteria. Nocardia pneumonia has a sub-acute presentation with mostly cough with thick sputum and fever. Generally, hemoptysis is uncommon. Chest radiography shows nodular infiltrations involving bilateral lung fields.

Extrapulmonary manifestations are common, the brain is the most commonly involved organ. It is associated with dense bilateral infiltrates with cavitating nodules and subacute brain abscesses.

The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole. Severe disease is treated with a combination of cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone, or imipenem.

Note: Mnemonic SNAP: 

Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice for Nocardia.

For Actinomyces, Penicillins are the drugs of choice.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient came with complaints of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. The urine pregnancy test was positive. Her thyroid profile is given below. She reports that her mother has Graves disease. What is the drug of choice for her present condition?

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) - decreased

T4 - increased
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of hyperthyroidism in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. Propylthiouracil is the drug of choice for this patient. 

Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It inhibits the peroxidase enzyme, which catalyzes the coupling reaction of iodotyrosyl residues; thus reducing thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits peripheral iodothyronine deiodination.

Uses:

  • As a definitive treatment and to control remission in Graves disease
  • In conjunction with radioactive iodine
  • Preoperatively to control the disorder requiring surgery

Adverse effects:

  • Agranulocytosis is reversible once the drug is stopped
  • Most common is urticarial rash
  • Teratogenic potential limited to methimazole and carbimazole leading to
    • Fetal aplasia cutis 
    • Choanal and esophageal atresia

Propylthiouracil does not cross the placental barrier whereas methimazole and carbimazole cross the placental barrier leading to teratogenicity. Therefore, propylthiouracil is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism in 1st trimester of pregnancy (period of organogenesis). Propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity, following which it is replaced with methimazole (or carbimazole) in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

Other options:

Option D: Levothyroxine is a thyroid hormone preparation used in the treatment of hypothyroidism and myxedema coma.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room. His vitals are as shown below. His vitals did not improve on fluid resuscitation. On FAST examination, there was fluid present in the retroperitoneal space. The patient was shifted to the operating room for laparotomy. What is the intravenous agent of choice for this patient?
  • Pulse rate- 100 bpm
  • Blood pressure(BP)- 80/40 mmHg
  • SpO2- 95%
  • Respiratory rate- 30 per minute
  • GCS- 15/15

(FAST- Focussed Assessment of Sonography in Trauma)
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice in this patient. Ketamine indirectly stimulates the cardiovascular system and is thus useful in this patient as he has come with a traumatic injury to the abdomen and is hemodynamically unstable.

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. It also causes dissociative anesthesia.

On the cardiovascular system, it directly has a cardio-depressive effect and indirectly stimulates it by activating the sympathetic system and inhibiting the vagus nerve. It predominantly shows a stimulatory effect hence causing tachycardia, increased cardiac output, and increased systemic and pulmonary hypertension.

On the respiratory system, it has a bronchodilator effect on bronchial smooth muscles. It increases salivary secretion and bronchial secretion. It also acts on other systems and increases the intracranial and intraocular pressures.

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures, psychiatric illness, or vascular aneurysms. It is also contraindicated in open eye injuries and eye surgeries

Adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Option B: Propofol is the most commonly used parenteral anesthetic. It is cerebro-protective by decreasing cerebral metabolic rate. It produces dose-dependent hypotension.

Option C: Thiopentone belongs to the barbiturate group. It is cerebro-protective and is an anticonvulsant. It leads to hypotension due to vasodilation. It is contraindicated in patients with obstructive airway disease, severe cardiovascular instability, and shock, history of porphyrias.

Option D: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine. It is used in treating seizures and is used in daycare surgeries as an induction agent due to its short half-life.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with a history of diabetes mellitus was diagnosed with major depression. He attempted suicide by consuming a bottle of glipizide tablets. What is the antidote of choice for this case?
questions.solution:
The antidote of choice for the above case scenario suggestive of sulfonylurea overdose (glipizide belongs to the sulfonylurea group) which resulted in severe hypoglycemia is octreotide.

Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue. It inhibits the secretion of growth hormone. It binds to somatostatin-2 receptors on pancreatic beta cells and blocks the Ca2+ influx resulting in a decrease in insulin secretion. Hence, it can be used to correct the hypoglycemia caused by sulfonylurea. overdose.

Other uses of octreotide:

  • Acromegaly
  • Esophageal varices
  • Thyrotrope adenomas
  • Carcinoid tumors
  • Adenomas secreting VIP(watery diarrhea)
  • Diagnostic imaging of neuroendocrine tumors
  • Sulfonylurea toxicity

Adverse effects: 

  • Injection site pain
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Gallstones

Other options: 

Option A: Glucagon can rectify hypoglycemia by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. However, it is not routinely administered as it can stimulate insulin release and is not useful in glycogen-depleted patients.

Option C: Intravenous dextrose is not given because when administered it creates a hyperglycemic state thus stimulating insulin release, causing hypoglycemia again.

Option D: Leucovorin (folinic acid) is the antidote of choice for methotrexate overdose.

questions.text: A patient with calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals in the urine is diagnosed with ethylene glycol poisoning. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Fomepizole is the drug of choice for the treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning.

Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning:

  • Fomepizole (preferred) or ethanol (if fomepizole is unavailable) - inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Sodium bicarbonate - correct systemic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis - for elevated toxic alcohol levels, severe acid-base derangements, or evidence of end-organ toxicity
  • Co-factors (folic acid, thiamine, and pyridoxine) - optimizes non-toxic metabolic pathways for the elimination of parent alcohol or its metabolites

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient came with complaints of easy fatiguability and back pain for the past 2 months. She gives a history of night sweats, dry skin, vaginal dryness, decrease libido since one year, and a right wrist fracture 3 months back. On investigation, her T-score is found to be –2.6. What is the drug of choice for her present complaint?
questions.solution:
Zoledronate (bisphosphonates) is the drug of choice for her present complaint i.e., back pain. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-menopausal osteoporosis and bisphosphonates are the drug of choice for this condition.

Zoledronate mainly targets the calcium of remodeling bone. It inhibits bone resorption by inducing apoptosis of osteoclast and inhibition of the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway. 

Therapeutic uses:

  • Post-menopausal and steroid-induced osteoporosis
  • Paget's disease
  • Tumor-induced osteolysis
  • Hypercalcemia

Adverse effects:

  • Oral intake causes esophagitis and esophageal erosion.
  • Intravenous intake causes infusion reactions like skin flushing, flu-like symptoms, muscle, and joint aches.
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Osteonecrosis of jaw bone
  • Increased risk of femoral shaft fractures

Postmenopausal osteoporosis is an exaggerated form of bone depletion that accompanies aging and loss of gonadal activity. Other risk factors of osteoporosis are:

  • Age
  • Female sex
  • Alcohol
  • Smoking
  • Previous history of fragility fractures
  • Family history of hip fracture
  • Low body mass index- less than 18.5 kg/m2
  • Excessive usage of glucocorticoids

They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are fractures of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. 

Other options: 

Option A: Estrogen supplementation is not effective for postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Option C: Teriperatide is a parathormone analogue that is used in the treatment of severe osteoporosis (T-score < –2.5).

Option D: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANK receptors and is used for severe osteoporosis (T-score < –2.5).

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who just came back from a trip to Brazil presents with fever, headache, and rash for the last 3 days. He is diagnosed with Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of the drug which should be used to treat him?

choices.text: Acts on 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Acts on transpeptidase and inhibits cell wall synthesis
Acts on 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis

questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the drug of choice for Rocky Mountain spotted fever. It belongs to the tetracycline group of antimicrobials. It acts on the 30s bacterial ribosome subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Therapeutic uses of tetracyclines include:

  • Rickettsial infections such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, scrub typhus, and Q fever
  • Pneumonia due to Steptococcus pneumonia, H. influenzae and atypical organisms
  • Sexually transmitted infections like Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Prevention and treatment of anthrax
  • Brucella, Bartonella, Borrelia infections
  • Mycobacterium marinum (swimming pool granuloma)

Tetracyclines are incompletely absorbed from the gut, leading to alteration of the gut flora due to the high concentration which is left unabsorbed in the intestines. This can cause an overgrowth of some organisms such as yeasts, Enterococci and Pseudomonas during prolonged tetracycline therapy. Children treated with tetracyclines may develop permanent brown discoloration of the teeth. The teratogenic effect associated with tetracyclines is their deposition in the fetal skeleton during pregnancy and depression of bone growth in infants.

Hepatotoxicity and nephrotoxicity can also occur. Demeclocycline causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and has been used for the treatment of SiADH. Other side effects include idiopathic intracranial hypertension and vestibular toxicity.

The main mechanism of resistance to tetracyclines is by a decreased antibiotic influx or acquisition of an energy-dependent efflux pump for the drug. Other mechanisms include a ribosomal protein that displaces tetracycline from its target and enzymatic inactivation of tetracyclines.

Other options:

Option A: Inhibition of DNA gyrase, topoisomerase IV is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones.

Option B: The antibiotics which act on the 50s subunit of bacterial ribosome include chloramphenicol, macrolides, clindamycin, linezolid, and streptogramins.

Option C: Blocking of the transpeptidase enzyme and inhibition of cell wall synthesis is the mechanism of action of penicillins.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient diagnosed with Parkinson's disease is on levodopa for 1 year. He developed involuntary, rapid, irregular movements of hands, face, and legs 2 days back. What is the first line of treatment for the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of levodopa-induced dyskinesia. The first line of treatment for this condition is Amantadine.

Normally, dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway provides continuous (tonic) stimulation to the dopaminergic receptors in the striatum. In Parkinson's disease, there is a loss of these tonic signals as there is a loss of dopaminergic neurons of the nigrostriatal pathway. This reduced dopaminergic activity is compensated by the increased glutaminergic activity in the striatum.

Levodopa that is administered in Parkinson's disease provides pulsatile (intermittent) signals to these dopamine receptors. Recent studies indicate that the overactivity of the glutaminergic neurons in the striatum and pulsatile dopaminergic therapy (instead of normal tonic stimulation) leads to altered signaling in the striatal neurons resulting in levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

Amantadine inhibits the NMDA receptors(glutaminergic receptors) thereby mediating an anti-dyskinetic effect. It also has an anti-viral effect by interfering in the function of M2 protein and inhibiting viral replication. It is used in the treatment of influenza.

Adverse effects:

  • Livedo reticularis is the appearance of non-blanching purplish dermal streaks
  • Edema
  • Contraindicated in renal, cardiovascular disease

The image below shows livedo reticularis:

Other options:

Option A: Apomorphine is a dopamine receptor agonist used in 'off' episodes of levodopa therapy.

Option B: Entacapone is a catechol-O-methyl transferase inhibitor and is used in 'off' episodes and as adjunctive therapy in Parkinson's disease.

Option D: Selegiline is an irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor-B and is used along with levodopa in mild or early Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region as shown in the image. What is the preferred drug to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
A child with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica. It is due to zinc deficiency. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred drug.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene, SLC39A4, found on chromosome 8q24.3, which leads to zinc deficiency.

Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip.

Diagnosis by clinical features and low plasma zinc levels. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 mg/kg/24 h). 

Mnemonic- DEAL for Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

D – Diarrhoea

E – Eczematous dermatitis

A - Alopecia

L – Lethargy

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents with the complaint of dropping objects from her hands during morning hours and during exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. EEG shows 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow waves that are enhanced by photic stimulation. What is the drug of choice for seizures in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome). The drug of choice for the seizure in this girl is sodium valproate. 

It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning with preserved consciousness. The jerks can manifest as dropping objects along with absence seizures. Sleep deprivation, alcohol, and photic stimulation act as triggers. The EEG shows 4-5 polyspike and slow-wave discharges. Levetiracetam, lamotrigine, and topiramate are the other alternatives used.

Other options:

Option 3: Vigabatrin is the drug of choice for infantile spasm.

questions.text:
An HIV patient presents with fever, cough, chest discomfort, and shortness of breath for 1 week. On chest CT, a halo sign is seen. On LPCB preparation, septate hyphae and conidiophores are seen. On the culture of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, black colonies with galactomannan assay positive are obtained. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this condition?

(LPCB- Lactophenol cotton blue)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Voriconazole is the preferred drug in this condition. 

Invasive aspergillosis occurs due to infection with Aspergillus species. Most cases of invasive aspergillosis involve the lungs. The clinical features include fever, cough which may be productive, chest discomfort, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath.

It is often seen in immunocompromised or debilitated due to prolonged treatment with antibiotics, steroids, and cytotoxics.

Other manifestations of aspergillus species are allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and superficial infections of the eye, external ear, and nasal sinuses.

Diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis is made when the following findings are observed:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

The image below shows septate hyphae with 45o branching and conidiophores:

The image below shows the halo sign on the CT scan:

Other options:

Option A: Itraconazole can be used for the treatment of chronic aspergillosis if there is resistance or failure of voriconazole.

Option C: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for mucormycosis and is the gold standard for induction treatment for cryptococcal meningitis when used in combination with 5-flucytosine. It can be used as a secondary treatment for invasive aspergillosis.

Option D: 5- fluorocytosine is useful in invasive candidiasis, and cryptococcal meningitis if combined with Amp B.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complained of low mood, decreased appetite, and loss of weight for the past 2 months. He mentions that he feels worthless and has decreased interest in activities. He also complains of great difficulty falling asleep. He has past history of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should be preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has major depression with insomnia, decreased appetite, and weight loss. The preferred drug for this patient is mirtazapine as it is an antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating properties.

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant (a noradrenergic-specific serotonin antagonist). It blocks the presynaptic α2 receptors and postsynaptic 5HT2 and 5HT3 receptors. The antagonism at serotonin receptors helps relieve anxiety and insomnia and stimulates appetite. It has a sedative property as it blocks the H1 receptors. Mirtazapine is used in the treatment of major depression with long-standing insomnia.

Adverse effects include sedation, increased appetite, weight gain, and rarely agranulocytosis. Sexual dysfunction is not a known side-effect of mirtazapine.

Atypical anti-depressants are those that act by unique mechanisms other than those of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), MAO inhibitors, and tricyclic antidepressants. It includes drugs like trazodone, mianserin, bupropion, mirtazapine, and amoxapine.

Other options:

Option A: Fluoxetine is an SSRI used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects include anxiety, irritability, and decreased libido.

Option B: Venlafaxine is an SNRI used in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects are nausea, sexual dysfunction, and sustained elevation of blood pressure.

Option C: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant used in the treatment of major depression and nocturnal enuresis. Its use should be limited in heart diseases as it has quinidine-like effects on cardiac conduction, and hence, it is avoided in this patient.

questions.text: What is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for the management of metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. In GIST, it inhibits the mutant c-KIT gene. Its adverse effects include myelosuppression, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, edema, and periorbital swelling.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation associated with GIST is the c-KIT gene mutation. They compromise 1-3% of all gastrointestinal tumors. The most common sites are the stomach, small bowel, and rectum. They are considered to have metastatic potential if larger than 5cm.

Symptoms of GIST include pain abdomen, nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, and malena.

They are diagnosed on endoscopy and can be confirmed by targeted biopsy by endoscopic ultrasound. The primary mode of treatment is surgical resection if they are easily resectable. Smaller tumors (<5cm) are treated by wedge resection and larger tumors (>5cm) may require gastrectomy or duodenectomy, with 3-6 months of imatinib therapy before operation. Imatinib therapy should be continued for large tumors with high malignant potential.

Other options:

Option A: Erlotinib is an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic cancer. 

Option C: Sorafenib is an intracellular kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Dasatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of imatinib-resistant CML.

Related Pearl: Indications for Imatinib

BCR-ABL kinase mutations

  • Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML)
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

C-KIT mutations

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

PDGFR mutations

  • Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CML)

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively, she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient developing fever, tachycardia, and rigidity of the masseter muscle after being administered halothane is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Patients with positive family history and patients with congenital myopathies are at increased risk for the development of this condition.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive management includes rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia.

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant. It is not indicated for the management of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice to ameliorate the non-neural manifestations of mucopolysaccharidosis II?
questions.solution:
Elaprase (recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice to ameliorate the non-neural manifestations of mucopolysaccharidosis II/Hunter syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of lysosomal storage metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. There are 7 distinct classes of mucopolysaccharidosis which are further subcategorized.

Hunter syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused due to deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase. This enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. It almost exclusively manifests in males.

Clinical features of Hunter syndrome are similar to Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I) except for the corneal clouding and slow progression of central nervous system deterioration. Other features are:

  • Short stature
  • Hearing impairment
  • Coarse facial features
  • Mongolian spots
  • Joint stiffness, carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Chronic diarrhea
  • Valvular cardiac disease
  • Intellectual disability
  • Spastic paraplegia
  • Communicating hydrocephalus

Diagnosis:

  • Newborn screening using dried blood spots
  • Semiquantitative analysis of increased urinary glycosaminoglycans(GAG)
  • Quantitative analysis of single GAG
  • Definitive diagnosis by enzyme assay

Elaprase (recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice to ameliorate the non-neural manifestations. Early hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may have some effects. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation when done before 9 months of age results in normal cognitive development. Transplantation does not have any effect on neuropsychological manifestation when impaired cognition is already present at the time of transplantation. Symptomatic therapy is given for most neurological manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme (recombinant L-iduronidase) is approved as enzyme replacement therapy for Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I).

Option B: Alglucosidase alfa (recombinant α-glucosidase) is the enzyme replacement therapy for Pompe disease.

Option D: Nagalzyme (recombinant N-acetylgalactosamine-4-sulfatase) is the enzyme replacement therapy for Maroteux-Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina. Whiff's test was positive and microscopy of the discharge is shown below.  What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, a positive Whiff test and clue cells on microscopy point towards a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Metronidazole (oral or intravaginal) or intravaginal clindamycin are considered the drugs of choice. 

The male partner should be treated in case of recurrent infections of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female patient presents with diminished vision, headache, and eye pain. She had a history of herpes infection. On examination, there is an increase in IOP. The ophthalmologist prescribes an eye drop for increased IOP. After a week, the patient presents with herpetic keratitis. Which of the following is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis?

(IOP- Intraocular pressure)
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis in this patient.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue and acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow thus reducing the IOP. Latanoprost is preferred over β-blockers due to its decreased systemic side effects. 

Prostaglandin analogues induce the release of endogenous prostaglandins in the iris and ciliary which enhances the cell-to-cell spread of HSV resulting in reactivation of the herpes infection. 

Adverse effects:

  • conjunctival hyperaemia
  • eyelash thickening 
  • iris pigmentation 
  • promotion of herpetic keratitis in a patient with a history of herpes infection
  • if used preoperatively, cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a bilateral, symmetrical disease with an adult-onset type. In this condition, there is an increase in the IOP due to trabecular sclerosis leading to decreased aqueous outflow. The clinical features include headache, difficulty in dark adaptation, frequent change of glasses, and blurring of vision. 

On ocular examination, an open anterior chamber angle, glaucomatous optic nerve head changes, visual field defects, and an increased IOP of more than 21mmHg are noted.

Other options:

Option A- Timolol is a non-selective β-blocker that decreases the IOP by reducing the aqueous humor production through blockade of the β-receptors on the ciliary epithelium. The adverse effects include:

  • Ocular effects are allergy, decreased corneal sensation, and punctate keratitis
  • Systemic effects-
    • Potentially fatal bronchospasm in asthmatic patients and reversible airway diseases due to blockade of β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle
    • Heart blocks, bradycardia, worsening of heart failure, and hypotension are some of the cardiovascular adverse effects

Option C- Brimonidine is a selective alpha-2 agonist which decreases aqueous synthesis and increases uveoscleral outflow. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and, hence, causes drowsiness and CNS depression. It is contraindicated in infants and children.

Option D- Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases IOP by reducing aqueous formation. The main adverse effect is the bitter taste following administration. It is contraindicated in people with allergies to sulfonamide antibiotics. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient complains of pruritis. He feels intense pruritus and has painful, red streaks between his fingers and in the groin area. He states that the itchiness is worse at night. Other students from his college dormitory also present with similar complaints. An image of his skin on physical examination is shown below. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of scabies. Management of scabies involves topical application of 5% permethrin cream.

The image shows a magnified view of a burrowing trail of the scabies mite. The scaly patch on the left was caused by the scratching and marks the mite's entry point into the skin. The mite has burrowed to the top-right, where it can be seen as a dark spot at the end. Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis.

The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. Burrows present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. It is created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin.

Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.

Other treatment options - topical application of 1% lindane lotion, benzyl benzoate, esdepalletrin (bioallethrin), crotamiton, and precipitated sulfur.

Other options:

Option B- Oral albendazole is used in the treatment of larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

The image below shows cutaneous larva migrans:

 

The image below shows larva currens:

 

Option D- Topical corticosteroids are used in certain cases of bed bugs. They present as pruritic maculopapular lesions with a visible hemorrhagic punctum in the center. Three or four lesions may be arranged in a line or a curve pattern which is called breakfast‐lunch‐dinner alignment.

questions.text:
An elderly male patient with a history of Mycobacterium avium complex infection presented with fatigue and a dragging sensation in the left upper abdomen. On examination, massive splenomegaly with no lymphadenopathy was found. His peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the drug of choice for this malignancy?

Blood routine report- Pancytopenia

Bone marrow aspirate- dry tap

Immunohistochemistry

CD19      - Positive
CD22      - Positive
CD11c     - Positive
CD25      - Positive
CD103    - Positive
CD123    - Positive
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the findings of leukemic cells with fine hair-like projections in the peripheral smear are suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is the drug of choice for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon α, pentostatin, and cladribine. However, cladribine, a purine analogue is the preferred drug of choice as complete remission with cladribine occurs clinically in the majority of patients and long-term disease-free survival is frequent. Cladribine is administered daily for 7 days by continuous intravenous infusion.

Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor.

Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.

Hairy cell Leukemia:

Most patients present with symptoms of cytopenias or splenomegaly. Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells (do not confuse with myelofibrosis).

CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 are the characteristic immunophenotypes diagnostic of Hairy cell leukemia. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 can also test positive for Hairy cell leukemia.

There is an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections (Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) in hairy cell leukemia. This is possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Out of the atypical mycobacteria, Mycobacterium kansasii infection is a unique feature of hairy-cell leukemia.

Staining:

Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies. 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and yields positive results in ≈95% of the cases.

Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear is an important diagnostic finding. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also.

Typical hairy cells are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections.

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar
